@pluskid Possibly due to the recent executor manager refactor?

```
ctx = mx.gpu(0)
data = mx.symbol.Variable("data")
net = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data, kernel=(3,3), num_filter=64)
net = mx.symbol.Activation(data=net, act_type="relu")
net = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=net,kernel=(3,3), num_filter=64)
net = mx.symbol.Activation(data=net, act_type="relu")
net = mx.symbol.Pooling(data=net, pool_type="max", kernel=(2,2))
executor = net.simple_bind(ctx=ctx,data=(1,3,512,512),grad_req="null")
executor = executor.reshape(allow_up_sizing=True, data = (1,3,400,600))
executor.forward(is_train=False)
```

The rand_crop means if the input size of the network is less than the actual image size, it will randomly crop. The crop_ratio is different, and it is used in affine transformation.
There is one commit in between Jan 22 and Feb 7 that slows down the speed... Trying to find that.

@tornadomeet @piiswrong I agree, I think it would be a good idea to separate context info and parameter values. Then we always load the parameters into cpu memory and initialise the model based on the specific context.

FWIW, cudnn's algorithm selection as of v3/v4 can be suboptimal (even for common convnets like VGG-16), so using the 'Find' variant (which uses an autotuner to select the algorithm) is generally recommended for maximum performance vs the 'Get' variant (which MXNet uses, and which relies on heuristics and can result in suboptimal algorithm choices). See e.g. https://github.com/soumith/cudnn.torch/blob/28c2f6e76a0d3671ce127197c25e39c5ee4be627/SpatialConvolution.lua#L186-L190

I'm not sure on which BN implementation was being reported there, but IIRC the FB SpatialBatchNormalization GPU implementation was faster than (at least the initial) cudnn v4 BatchNormalization implementation.

@ajtulloch Thanks for pointing this out. One problem is MXNet pre-allocates all memory to do memory optimization. This function seems to allocate memory internally and need to be called before user memory allocation. @tqchen @antinucleon Any ideas?
I have already tried to modify it, but I'm sorry that the mxnet code seems quite difficult for me to understand, such as the function unpack_patch2col

I'm not sure if it's the case here FWIW, but it might be worth just logging which algorithms are chosen by `Get` vs `Find` (even just running the Torch version with cudnn.benchmark = true/false) and making sure MXNet is choosing the right kernels. IIRC MXNet uses multiple host threads to launch kernels on multiple devices (right?), so it doesn't have to add the Torch nn.DataParallelTable multi-threading hack needed to overcome the launch overhead for the tiled FFT kernels.

I'm not sure if that helps, but I tried to research a bit further into this. I installed the R package with option `--no-test-load` to check out where files are placed and what they look like. It turned out that the two shared objects are placed as follows:

```

> ~/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/3.2/mxnet/libs/libmxnet.so
> ~/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/3.2/mxnet/libs/x86_64/mxnet.so

```

Note that, on another system (an x86_64 laptop with Ubuntu and without cuda; everything works nicely on this one), it looks as follows:

```

> ~/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/3.2/mxnet/libs/mxnet.so
> ~/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/3.2/mxnet/libs/libmxnet.so

```

So it seems that, in contrast to the one system on which it works, the two shared objects are in different directories. I then made symbolic links such that both objects are found in both directories `~/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/3.2/mxnet/libs/` and `~/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/3.2/mxnet/libs/x86_64`. Voil, the package could be loaded. I still have some issues related to the ACML library that is linked into my R version, but I will first try to solve those myself. And they are certainly unrelated to the problem discussed in this thread.
